comments.commentBody: yeh, the writing is on the wall, a short career for sid the ol' man.

As soon as Perry explains to us who will maintain the US stockpile of nuclear weapons once he abolishes the Dept of Energy, we can move on. Or is he going to outsource it to local and state government? Why then do we need a federal government if states can do it best. Better yet, why does Perry want to head an inconsequential federal government?

What a thought provoking article! "Out of the box" thinking for education.
The Indians and Chinese are working to create a middle class, while we are destroying one. We have a political party that unrealisticly wants to hold onto a wealthy class, while India is breaking down their caste system. Which democracy will survive?
Unless the 2012 election results in a defeat of the power of the party of "no", our ability to support a middle class is doomed.
Thanks for an eye opener.

The rout is on. Oregon takes a 35-16 lead. It's time to ask the question: If Oklahoma beats Oklahoma State to end the regular season, does Oregon deserve a rematch against L.S.U.?

Does a Duck go Quack?

( Of course it does, now let's bring back LSU one more time...)

Although I agree with reader 1 about the usurpation of vast sums of money by the wealthy, it does not have to end grimly for our country. There is much talk about teacher evaluation these days, how poor ones with tenure are not removed, and there is truth to that. Of course there are many dedicated teachers who give of themselves day in and out.

When I was growing up a few decades ago, we had simple textbooks and blackboards and in a parochial school we learned, some excelled. What is so often missing from discussion about education in the United States is the huge influence parents and siblings have on their children, and the attitudes given children by the parents is profound, attitudes likely already formed in most children by the time they have arrived at school. Many children with little interest in learning and little encouragement at home, and those with poor boundaries around other children, create a chaotic learning environment for all. It is unfair to place the burden of motivation solely on teachers.

What needs to happen, in my view, is a fundamental societal shift toward embracing learning, and rather than label intelligent children 'nerds', have leadership in our country which shows education in its most positive light. If we are left behind other countries which extol education and skill learning, the responsibility lies with us. To assume it will end badly is to assume that nothing can, or will, change in the future. Clearly it can change, if we as a nation want it to.

The need for a fair press is obvious, if we are not to have bought elections. The media is our only hope of educating voters. The PAC's will do their best to missinform.
Karl Rove's plan to create a one party system in our country may result after all. The control of the courts by republicans is well on its way. After republican administrations being able to appoint judges in 28 of the previous 40 years prior to the Obama Presidency, the courts are packed from the right. Decisions regarding election laws will continue to favor the corporations and the wealthy.
The 2012 election will be critical for democracy.

He was a very complex man at both professional and personal levels, mono-manical against the commies and everything he thought was corrosive to US. Clint takes up this kind of highly controversial subject; he couldn't be too open or direct but, circumspect as he tried to be, he shed enough light to make J. Edgar subject of further interest.

Benny Acosta (comment #5) has the big picture in focus. The addicts are overdosing, yet summon the strength to fight over the last fix. To clarify for the terminally myopic, when global temps rise 3.6 degrees farenheit, the ecosystem itself becomes a net carbon source and a death spiral begins. The permafrost melts and wildfires and decay transform green to black. Grain-producing regions desertify. Thirty percent  of coastal wetlands submerge under salt water. Coral beds, the basis of the oceanic ecosystem, die. The best way to unite feuding parties is a mutual threat. But when it is not acknowledged, conditions deteriorate. Deserts are encroaching already. Wildfires are rife. The Western Black Rhino was just declared extinct. A rhino is one hell of a canary in a coal mine. Finance exploits the processes of life without regard for the future. All the weapons and money in the world cannot bring back those rhinos. Humanity will be united, one way or the other, in life or death. Pick one.

A rhinoceros is one hell of a canary in a coalmine. Humanity is hag-ridden, and the slaves subsist in a malignant fantasy of freedom. Some say denial is the first stage of mourning. Mourning is definitely on the menu. The elaborate and esoteric traceries of finance are cement galoshes on the vital processes of life. Avarice is an insatiable parasite. It must be tempered, else it condemn the host to death and extinction.
If we fight we should fight to win. Starting with Korea that concept has seemed to escape the politicians in charge.

Was it worth it, is the question I asked myself on July 11, 1969, just 7 days before my 19th birthday. In-country for six months, my sense of patriotism and adventure was exhausted. If someone told me, one more KIA or WIA is needed to win the war. I would have told them, then and today, it's not worth it.

I truly hope you figure out the something you want to do for your brothers, Jason or Dennis. Maybe it will become something you've done for my brothers, as well.

Hey Jim, thanks for your awesome article! You speak for us all.

Jeff
Class of 2006
U.S.M.A.

Now that the U.S. Military is finally leaving Iraq, the comments of officers in this article who are vacating Hussein's infamous palaces are pretty outrageous and give the impression that they are proud of the Iraq neo-colonial, conquering "war". Hundreds of Iraqi civilians died, were driven out of their homes, and endured a religiously based civil war while 4,000+ Americans died, 30,000+ were injured (many gravely) and over $1 trillion was wasted...for what??

Thanks for your feedback and suggestions. Maybe it is time to change that cartoon drawing of a racing car. It has adorned the blog since the blog started at the beginning of the 2006 season. Wow, 6 seasons already!!
Webber makes for great material, indeed.

As an American, it is nice to be able to read about Formula One, in the news paper. I really appreciate the stories that Mr. Spurgeon submitts. There are a few improvments that I would like to suggest.
The Picture that appears on the NYTimes/IHT page for "Formula One: A View From the Paddock" is not a Formula One car. It looks more like an Indy Car, or Champcar.
Please give us F-1 junkies a little bit of something to read, even when there is no race. Reuters has some stuff that I read every few days, but Brad's articals are much better.
Finally, I hear way too much about Lewis Hamilton. I realize there has been a lot to write about with the Massa / Hamilton thing, and Hamilton's penalties & poor races. I'm much more interested in what Mark Webber is doing.

Keep up the good work! I hope that Formula One makes it to the United States next year.

Thanks for your feedback and suggestions. Maybe it is time to change that cartoon drawing of a racing car. It has adorned the blog since the blog started at the beginning of the 2006 season. Wow, 6 seasons already!!
Webber makes for great material, indeed.

It is fair to highlight the president's efforts to ameliorate poverty through Federal programs in the face of the dastardly, obstructionist Republicans. But exactly when does this president take ownership the economy in which so many are impoverished?

The average monthly snap benefit is 133.79 for an individual.

http://www.statehealthfacts.org/comparetable.jsp?cat=1&ind=26

Now on its face that doesn't seem like very much at all, roughly 5 dollars a day. However, when on considers that it is supposed to be a supplement, not a meal ticket. It becomes clear that this program is offering a disincentive to work. As a recently graduated college student, I can tell you I can and have eaten for a month for around $150 a month. The things is Food stamps shouldn't being paying for an individuals monthly groceries. It should help them get by, not be a meal ticket. Especially, for single, working age men and women. Why should joe taxpayer pad their income so that they won't get off their butts and take jobs that, they think they are too good for.

As an independent voter who now leans right due to the crazy fiscal spending of the Democratic party since Obama took office, no one is suggesting Government is the enemy. Big government is the enemy. Government intruding in to every aspect of life, and usually through the guide of spending enormous amounts of money while saying it will safe money in the long run is the enemy. Government programs wasting taxpayer money, like in Solyndra, instead of letting the markets do that is the enemy. Obamacare, which no self-respecting economist thinks will save money, is the enemy. The constant demagoguing using class warfare and splitting the country is the enemy. President Obama is supposed to be the President of the United States, not the left wing of the Dem party. I a sure everyone has some kind of a story where government helped them. I served years in the military and profited from educational programs that helped me get a graduate degree. But I also became a big tax payer. Governments that have spent so much money they have no choice but to tax the successful is the enemy. Governments that increase in size, and therefore in crease in the amount of pensions they will award down the line are the enemy. Politicians that make promises they know that when the bill comes due they won't be in office is the enemy. Collective bargaining for unions isn't bargaining when they are talking to Democratic leaders. The only bargaining is against the tax payer. That is the enemy. I could go on and on and on.... Democrats need to learn that some programs are NOT worth any price on the taxpayers back. They become the enemy.

I'm continually amazed by the economic blindness of people like Blow and his readers.  Its little wonder the state of New York is a financial disaster.  I look forward to the day your socialist state commune goes bankrupt.  Good riddance to you and those like you Mr. Blow.  Government IS the enemy.

There is nothing benevolent about any government benefit. Government benefits depend upon the initiation of force without provocation against peaceful people to obtain the funds via taxation, and they make the recipients of the funds into both government dependents and accessories after the fact of the introduction of violence into society. There is not s shred of generosity involved in collecting and dispersing OPM (sounds like opium, is equally addicting, stands for other people's money).

Jesus of Nazareth was certainly qualified to speak on what it means to be a "neighbor" to those less-fortunate than ourselves. He explicitly addressed that concern in his parable of The Good Samaritan, which remains to this day the most oft-quoted words of wisdom on the subject. Examine the parable closely and you will see that Jesus very explicitly had the Good Samaritan use only his own resources to care for and succor the welfare of the unfortunate stranger he saved from certain death by his kindness. And, as if to address those good-neighbor posers who would use OPM instead of their own money to benefit the poor, Jesus concluded his parable with these instructions: "Go, and do likewise."

The question is, why does the middle class continue to vote against their interests? There a couple reasons I can think of: 1) they've been duped and 2) they vote purely for social reasons. When you've married off financial conservatism and social conservatism, there is this block that is unbeatable. That is the scary part... that people would rather deny benefits to others over things that don't matter to them (like gay marriage) and doesn't affect them, rather than vote FOR things that WILl benefit them.

To #72:

But the Democratic party is NOT owned by anyone? Right.

The DP is owned by the public employee unions and corporate interests as well. NEITHER party represents my interests as a struggling self-employed person.

There are MILLIONS of people in this country like me, who are totally invisible. The idea that I can turn to the Democrats to help me is ridiculous. No huge wads of cash to offer them. Therefore, no power.

It's just show me the money. Once you understand that, life gets a little simpler.

In the meantime, this once great country burns.

@ Exlibra, #173:

And who do you think builds those cars that are bought by people who you think make too much money. I suppose you'd rather see them have no work at all and have to depend on government programs? Brilliant, just brilliant.

govt IS the enemy of fed income tax payers - SEE solyndra, etc.

My thought on an effective social program: GRADUATE MORE THAN 50% OF THE STUDENTS FROM PUBLIC HIGH SCHOOL.

How can people who depend on government help, be convinced to vote for those who would cut such help?

Those of us who believe in a safety net, need to get the message out that it makes no sense to vote for those who would hurt you.
